author: Shahul Hameed
title: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Unfair‚Ä¶‚Äù: Damian Lillard‚Äôs Ex-Teammate Gives His Verdict on 7x All-Star‚Äôs Bucks Move - EssentiallySports
text: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Unfair‚Ä¶‚Äù: Damian Lillard‚Äôs Ex-Teammate Gives His Verdict on 7x All-Star‚Äôs Bucks Move [](https://bit.ly/4113QfS) Follow Us Damian Lillard left the NBA world clueless throughout the 2023 off-season with his trade intentions. And, finally, days before the season opener, the 7x NBA All-Star got his nod from the Milwaukee Bucks franchise. Since then, Lillard hasn‚Äôt looked back as he got what he wished for, a run at the championship. However, it didn‚Äôt sit well with one of his former teammates, as he gave his verdict ahead of his reunion game. America‚Äôs Favorite Video Today Zach Collins, who moved to the San Antonio Spurs in 2021 after spending 3 years with the Portland Trail Blazers, commented on the big Bucks trade. Ahead of the Spurs‚Äô game against the Blazers, Collins made his verdict. He said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs definitely weird, it‚Äôs unfair‚Ä¶ to be in the transition when he is not here is definitely different.‚Äù Homecoming for [@zcollins_33]as he faces his former team. He goes one-on-one with [@DanWeissPBP]to talk about his return to Portland. [@spurs]| [#PorVida]| üì∫:BSSW [pic.twitter.com/IR6fkD7vba] ‚Äî Bally Sports San Antonio (@BallySportsSA) [December 29, 2023] This is a developing story! Providing feedback will help us make your experience better. The Fan's Perspective Enjoyed Your Read? Let us know how likely you are to recommend EssentiallySports to your friends! author: Cindy Wooden
title: The pope's 2023: A year of health challenges, travel and the synod - Catholic Review
text: The pope‚Äôs 2023: A year of health challenges, travel and the synod December 29, 2023By Cindy Wooden Catholic News Service Filed Under: Feature, News, Vatican, World News VATICAN CITY (CNS) ‚Äî Pope Francis‚Äô 2023 was a year of important trips made or postponed, a predecessor‚Äôs funeral and his own 10th anniversary as pope, a call to the world to act on climate change and a call to the Catholic Church to strengthen its mission by learning ‚Äúsynodality.‚Äù The Argentine pope, who was born Dec. 17, 1936, was to finish the year as an 87-year-old. As the oldest reigning pope in the last 120 years, Pope Francis‚Äô year was punctuated with hospitalizations, breathing difficulties and ongoing mobility challenges. The last pope to serve at his age was Pope Leo XIII, who died at the age of 93 in 1903. Pope Francis greets a newlywed couple at the end of his weekly general audience in the Paul VI Audience Hall at the Vatican Dec. 13, 2023. (CNS photo/Lola Gomez) For Pope Francis, the year began with mourning Pope Benedict XVI, who resigned in 2013 and died Dec. 31, 2022. Pope Francis spent the week after his death speaking about his predecessor, lauding his ‚Äúwisdom, tenderness, devotion‚Äù and lauding how his theology was a direct result of his faith. ‚ÄúHis explanation of the faith was carried out with the devotion of a man who has surrendered all of himself to God and who, under the guidance of the Holy Spirit, sought an ever-greater participation in the mystery of that Jesus who had fascinated him from his youth,‚Äù Pope Francis wrote in the introduction to a book published by the Vatican. Pope Francis presided over his predecessor‚Äôs funeral Jan. 5, and preaching about the Gospel rather than giving a eulogy as liturgical norms dictate, he built his homily around four quotations from Pope Benedict. The first of five foreign trips Pope Francis made in 2023 took him to Congo and then on an ecumenical peace mission to South Sudan. The trip with the Anglican archbishop of Canterbury and the moderator of the Presbyterian Church of Scotland had been set for July 2022, but was canceled because Pope Francis was experiencing intense pain in his knee. Even though he was well enough to travel in 2023, the knee continued to be a problem. Photos taken in his residence often showed him using a walker. He would be pushed in a wheelchair to his place when presiding at Mass in St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica and when greeting people at his general audiences. On days when it was not so painful, he would use a silver cane. Pope Francis spent nine days in Rome‚Äôs Gemelli hospital in June after undergoing a three-hour surgery to repair a hernia. Surgeons also removed several adhesions or bands of scar tissue that had formed after previous surgeries decades ago. Suffering from a respiratory infection, he also spent four days in March in the suite of rooms the Gemelli reserves for the pope. When he was experiencing respiratory difficulties again in late November, he went to the Gemelli Isola hospital for a CT scan but returned to his Vatican residence the same day. He was given intravenous antibiotics at home but kept many of his appointments, even if he did have an aide read his speeches for him. Pope Francis meets with participants from a seminar on ethics in health care management at the Vatican Nov. 30, 2023. (CNS photo/Vatican Media) The bronchial infection, which made his breathing very labored, forced him to cancel his planned trip to Dubai in the United Arab Emirates in early December for COP28; he would have been the first pope to attend a U.N. climate change summit. ‚ÄúAre we working for a culture of life or a culture of death?‚Äù he asked world leaders in his COP28 message read in Dubai by Cardinal Pietro Parolin, Vatican secretary of state. ‚ÄúTo all of you I make this heartfelt appeal: Let us choose life! Let us choose the future!‚Äù The destruction of the environment is ‚Äúa sin‚Äù that not only ‚Äúgreatly endangers all human beings, especially the most vulnerable,‚Äù he wrote to the leaders, but it also ‚Äúthreatens to unleash a conflict between generations.‚Äù In anticipation of the conference, Pope Francis in early October released ‚ÄúLaudate Deum‚Äù (‚ÄúPraise God‚Äù), a follow-up document to his 2015 encyclical ‚ÄúLaudato Si‚Äô, On Care for Our Common Home.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe must move beyond the mentality of appearing to be concerned but not having the courage needed to produce substantial changes,‚Äù he wrote in ‚ÄúLaudate Deum.‚Äù Making an even more urgent appeal for action than he did with ‚ÄúLaudato Si‚Äô,‚Äù the pope wrote that COP28 could ‚Äúrepresent a change of direction, showing that everything done since 1992 (with the adoption of the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change) was in fact serious and worth the effort, or else it will be a great disappointment and jeopardize whatever good has been achieved thus far.‚Äù The two major events Pope Francis was able to participate in were World Youth Day in Lisbon, Portugal, in August and the long-awaited first assembly of the Synod of Bishops on Synodality in October. WYD brought more than 1.5 million young people together and, in a letter for local youth day celebrations in November, Pope Francis described it as an ‚Äúevent that surpassed all our expectations. Our meeting in Lisbon was magnificent, a genuine experience of renewal, an explosion of light and joy!‚Äù Throughout his visit to Portugal, in meetings both with young people and with clergy, the pope‚Äôs refrain was that in the church there is room for ‚Äútodos, todos, todos‚Äù ‚Äî ‚Äúeveryone, everyone, everyone.‚Äù Pope Francis smiles as members of the assembly of the Synod of Bishops approach the end of their work Oct. 28, 2023, in the Paul VI Hall at the Vatican. (CNS photo/Vatican Media) ‚ÄúPlease, let us not convert the church into a customs office‚Äù where only the ‚Äújust,‚Äù ‚Äúgood,‚Äù and ‚Äúproperly married‚Äù can enter while leaving everyone else outside, he told Portuguese bishops, priests and pastoral workers. ‚ÄúNo. The church is not that,‚Äù he said, rather it is a place for ‚Äúrighteous and sinners, good and bad, everyone, everyone, everyone.‚Äù Interviewed by Italian television about the Oct. 4-29 assembly of the Synod of Bishops, the pope said, ‚ÄúThe result is positive. Everything was discussed with full freedom, and this is a beautiful thing.‚Äù Asked specifically about the assembly‚Äôs discussions about welcoming gay Catholics, Pope Francis responded: ‚ÄúWhen I say ‚Äòeveryone, everyone, everyone,‚Äô it‚Äôs the people. The church receives people, everyone, and does not ask what you are. Then, within the church, everyone grows and matures in their Christian belonging. It‚Äôs true that today it‚Äôs a bit fashionable to talk about this. The church receives everyone.‚Äù At his Mass concluding the synod assembly, the pope summarized his key hope for the synod, which will meet again in October 2024: ‚ÄúThe Lord will guide us and help us to be a more synodal and missionary church, a church that adores God and serves the women and men of our time, going forth to bring to everyone the consoling joy of the Gospel.‚Äù Just days before the synod opened, Pope Francis created 21 new cardinals from 16 nations, including Cardinal Robert F. Prevost, the Chicago-born prefect of the Dicastery for Bishops, and French Cardinal Christophe Pierre, the nuncio to the United States. In an interview with Mexican journalist Valentina Alazraki Dec. 12, the pope said he feels ‚Äúquite well‚Äù physically and his health continues to improve. Yet asked if people should be concerned about his health, he responded, ‚ÄúYes, a little bit, yes. I need them to pray for my health.‚Äù Read More Vatican News ‚ÄòListening is act of love,‚Äô says papal message to European youths Cardinal says Vatican is not moving toward accepting gay marriage Pope encourages persecuted Christians to stay strong in their witness ‚ÄòThe devil is a seducer,‚Äô pope says as he begins new series of talks Pope‚Äôs Christmas message: Say ‚Äòyes‚Äô to the Prince of Peace, ‚Äòno‚Äô to war At Christmas, God shows love through ‚Äòlittleness,‚Äô not power, pope says Copyright ¬© 2023 Catholic News Service/U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops Print

author: EFE
title: Euroliga: Voigtmann y Melli frenan a un impotente Baskonia en Mil√°n | Marca
text:
J ohannes Voigtmann y Nico Melli frenaron este jueves a un impotente Baskonia que cay√≥ en Mil√°n por 76-67 en un choque en el que los vitorianos no lograron superar su mal arranque ante un mermado Armani en la decimos√©ptima jornada de la Euroliga.
Ficha t√©cnica 76 - Armani Mil√°n (20+26+14+16): Flaccadori (14), Hall (-), Melli (21), Voigtmann (19) y Hines (8) -cinco inicial-, Poythress (5), Bortolani (-), Tonut (7), Baron (-), Kamagate (2) y Caruso (-). 67 - Baskonia (12+19+17+19): Miller-McIntyre (4), Marinkovic (10), D√≠ez (-), Sedekerskis (12) y Kotsar (2) -cinco inicial-, Chiozza (-), Rogkavopoulos (6), Howard (7), Diop (3), Costello (9) y Moneke (14). √Årbitros: Mehdi Difallah (Francia), Gytis Vilius (Lituania) y Josip Radojkovic (Croacia). Eliminaron por faltas personales a Costello (min.39). Se√±alaron falta antideportiva al visitante Howard (min.23). Incidencias: Partido correspondiente a la decimos√©ptima jornada de la Euroliga disputado en Mediolanum Forum de Mil√°n. Los italianos llegaron a manejar rentas de 22 puntos tras el descanso y aunque los azulgranas lograron reaccionar con jugadores menos habituales, apenas lograron bajar la diferencia por debajo de los 10 puntos.
Los bajos porcentajes exteriores y la concentraci√≥n defensiva fueron dos factores que marcaron un partido en el que los l√≠deres de los lombardos no pudieron jugar. En cambio, aparecieron hombres como el exbaskonista Johannes Voigtmann, con 19 puntos y 12 rebotes, y Nico Melli, con 24 cr√©ditos de valoraci√≥n, para reventar la pintura de los azulgranas, que solo encontraron chispazos de algunos jugadores.
El equipo lombardo entr√≥ mucho mejor en el partido con un parcial de 14-3. Los errores de los baskonistas se sucedieron en uno y otro lado con errores de marca y tres puntos en los primeros cinco minutos de un encuentro marcado por las ausencias de jugadores clave en los locales.
Los de Ettore Messina tuvieron m√°s paciencia en la elaboraci√≥n, mientras que los azulgranas se obsesionaron con el triple hasta que reaccionaron con la entrada de Chris Chiozza, que comenz√≥ a repartir juego y el Baskonia comenz√≥ a crecer.
Sin embargo, el segundo triple de Johannes Voigtmann dej√≥ un 20-12 que fren√≥ el empuje de un Baskonia que fue a rachas.
La defensa de los locales dieron puntos muy f√°ciles a un Mil√°n mucho m√°s intenso, que volvi√≥ a abrir hueco en un arranque de segundo cuarto cargado de errores vascos, que se encontraron con un activo Stefano Tonut.
Diego Flaccadori irrumpi√≥ para liderar a su equipo en ataque, Nico Melli cogi√≥ el testigo y Armani tom√≥ una renta superior a los diez puntos ante un Baskonia que sufr√≠a para anotar y solo sumaba al contragolpe.
Vanja Marinkovic fue el baskonista m√°s inspirado y evit√≥ una sangr√≠a de los locales, que incluso perdonaron a su rival con errores en varios tiros liberados y se fueron por delante con un 46-31, donde el acierto exterior y las p√©rdidas de bal√≥n marcaron la diferencia.
El paso por vestuarios no cambi√≥ mucho el partido. El Mil√°n sigui√≥ golpeando con comodidad y super√≥ los 20 puntos de distancia a lomos de un desatado Nico Melli y un acertado Johannes Voigtmann, que castigaron una y otra vez a un desquiciado Baskonia, incapaz de encontrar soluciones.
Todo coincidi√≥ adem√°s con la tercera falta personal de Markus Howard, una de las bazas vascas para intentar iniciar la remontada. De hecho, los azulgranas dieron un paso adelante en defensa y endosaron un parcial de 0-12, que les volvi√≥ a meter en el partido con diez minutos por delante, 60-48, con un quinteto at√≠pico.
Pero el Baskonia no consigui√≥ mantener la intensidad para defender su aro. Fue v√≠ctima de sus errores y no fue capaz de cerrar las v√≠as de agua que abrieron jugadores como Melli o Flaccadori.
Dusko Ivanovic continu√≥ creyendo en los hombres que ara√±aron los puntos a los italianos y aunque volvieron acercarse a diez puntos, desaprovecharon varias ocasiones claras de apretar a√∫n m√°s un marcador controlado por Armani, que aunque le falt√≥ acierto para cerrar el partido, apel√≥ a su defensa para evitar sustos y llevarse el duelo por 76-67.

author: Jessica Kwong
title: Terrifying moment rogue wave slams past seawall and hits fleeing beachgoers
text:
A storm-driven rogue wave crashed past a seawall in California and struck running beachgoers, pushed cars and turned streets into rivers.
The entire terrifying ordeal was captured on
video by a bystander in Ventura on Thursday.
A man can be seen walking calmly on the sand in the Pierpont neighborhood near Seaward Avenue as a swell in the distance approaches the seawall.
The water continues toward the shore and when it doesn‚Äôt stop, several people begin to flee.
Colin Hoag, who
 recorded the unusual occurrence, can be heard saying some expletives as he runs while still filming the swell continuing to climb up the street.
People can be heard screaming and a car is seen driving up the street with water surrounding it.
‚ÄòOh my god,‚Äô Haog says, as he stops several blocks away from the shore. Water is seen spreading more slowly.
Shop owners step outside to observe the streets turned into rivers. Some people wade more than ankle deep in the water.
‚ÄòI was able to capture this entire event on video this morning at the Seaward wall in Pierpont,‚Äô wrote Hoag on
Facebook on Thursday afternoon.
At least eight people were injured, according to Ventura County Fire Department Spokesman Andy Vansciver.
‚ÄòAll of the people in the area were swept down on to shore,‚Äô Vansciver told
KEYT. ‚ÄòMultiple vehicles in the area were moved around and swept around due to the impact and force of the water.‚Äô
There were at least 12 swift water rescues across Ventura County. The fire department urged the public to stay away form beaches.
The rogue wave was generated by powerful storms in the Pacific Ocean that have caused coastal flooding and evacuations across the California coast and in Hawaii.
Evacuation orders were in effect in Marin County on Thursday morning and later in the day in Santa Cruz County.
Waves were estimated to reach 28 to 40 feet, the National
Weather Service said.
Conditions were expected to improve in San Francisco on Friday morning, but forecasters said the worst could still be ahead in parts of southern California, with San Diego likely to see highest surf on Saturday. Los Angeles is on a high surf and coastal flooding advisory through Saturday at 10pm.

author: Viviana Urbina
title: El tiempo se est√° acabando: cient√≠ficos advierten sobre el fracaso de los puntos de inflexi√≥n clim√°ticos clave
text:
El tiempo se est√° acabando: cient√≠ficos advierten sobre el fracaso de los puntos de inflexi√≥n clim√°ticos clave
Los cient√≠ficos han publicado un nuevo estudio en el que advierten sobre el colapso de una corriente oce√°nica clave, y sus efectos podr√≠an tener consecuencias nefastas en todo el mundo. El informe tambi√©n analiza otros puntos de inflexi√≥n clim√°ticos.
A principios de este a√±o, Venezuela perdi√≥ su √∫ltimo glaciar. La capa de hielo de Groenlandia est√° perdiendo 30 millones de toneladas de hielo por hora. La p√©rdida de hielo del glaciar Thwaites, conocido como el "glaciar del fin del mundo", podr√≠a ser imparable. Un nuevo estudio resume el estado de la nieve y el hielo en la Tierra este a√±o.
Alcanzando el punto de inflexi√≥n
Los hallazgos de m√°s de 50 cient√≠ficos especializados en nieve y hielo, en un nuevo informe de la Iniciativa Internacional sobre el Clima de la Criosfera, resumen el estado de la nieve y el hielo en 2024. Los expertos coinciden en que ha sido un a√±o horrible para la criosfera de la Tierra como resultado del calentamiento global.
Los cient√≠ficos est√°n preocupados de que la Circulaci√≥n Meridional Atl√°ntica (AMOC por su sigla en ingl√©s) est√© en camino de colapsar. La AMOC es una corriente clave que rige los ciclos de calor en el Oc√©ano Atl√°ntico. El colapso de la corriente provocar√≠a un enfriamiento r√°pido en el Atl√°ntico Norte, un calentamiento en el hemisferio sur y cambios extremos en las precipitaciones. El norte de Europa podr√≠a enfriarse 5,4 grados Fahrenheit en s√≥lo una d√©cada.
Los cient√≠ficos pensaban que estos puntos de inflexi√≥n del clima estaban lejos de la realidad. Ahora parece m√°s probable que sucedan, con menos tiempo para evitar que sucedan. ‚ÄúLa ciencia m√°s reciente nos dice con m√°s confianza y m√°s certeza que es m√°s probable que sucedan estas cosas‚Äù, dice Helen Findlay, autora del informe y profesora y ocean√≥grafa biol√≥gica del Laboratorio Marino de Plymouth en Inglaterra.
‚ÄúCuanto m√°s tiempo registremos estas cosas y cuanto m√°s tiempo podamos observarlas y comenzar a comprenderlas y monitorearlas, habr√° m√°s certeza en el sistema y comenzaremos a comprender realmente c√≥mo funcionan estos puntos de inflexi√≥n‚Äù, contin√∫a Findlay.
El estado de la nieve y el hielo de la Tierra
44 cient√≠ficos destacados escribieron una carta abierta a los l√≠deres de los pa√≠ses n√≥rdicos en la que afirmaban que el colapso de la AMOC segu√≠a siendo ‚Äúmuy incierto‚Äù, pero hay evidencia de que el colapso est√° aumentando y que los riesgos se hab√≠an subestimado. Los cambios dram√°ticos en la AMOC probablemente conducir√≠an a un clima extremo sin precedentes y amenazar√≠an potencialmente la viabilidad de la agricultura en el noroeste de Europa.
El nuevo informe tambi√©n saca a la luz el riesgo de colapso de la AMOC. Se proyecta que dos tercios del hielo glaciar en los Alpes europeos se perder√°n para 2050 si las emisiones globales de gases de efecto invernadero contin√∫an en su rumbo actual. Se estima que 10 millones de personas corren el riesgo de inundaciones por desbordes glaciares en Islandia, Alaska y Asia.
Estas inundaciones ya est√°n ocurriendo. El agua de deshielo colapsa las presas de hielo e inunda r√°pidamente r√≠o abajo. Si las altas emisiones contin√∫an, el nivel del mar podr√≠a subir 3 metros en el siglo XXI, arrasando ciudades costeras seg√∫n los modelos.
¬øY ahora qu√©?
El informe se public√≥ mientras los l√≠deres mundiales se reun√≠an en Bak√∫, Azerbaiy√°n, para la conferencia clim√°tica COP29 de la ONU. El grupo espera ganar la atenci√≥n de los l√≠deres mundiales con el informe. "El sentido de urgencia no podr√≠a ser mayor. Hemos estado hablando de urgencia durante una d√©cada. Casi comienza a sentirse como una palabra in√∫til. ¬øQu√© es m√°s que ‚Äúurgente‚Äù? ¬ø‚ÄúCatastr√≥fico‚Äù? Se nos han acabado las formas de describirlo‚Äù, alega Julie Brigham-Grette, profesora de geociencias de la Universidad de Massachusetts Amherst y autora del nuevo informe.
El lunes (11) en Bak√∫, los l√≠deres mundiales acordaron nuevas reglas para un mercado global para el comercio de cr√©ditos de carbono. El mundo est√° ‚Äúen camino a la ruina‚Äù bajo las pol√≠ticas clim√°ticas actuales, dice el presidente de la COP29, Mukhtar Babyev, ministro de ecolog√≠a y recursos naturales de Azerbaiy√°n desde 2018. Los autores comunicaron claramente el consenso cient√≠fico, comenta Peter Neff, un glaci√≥logo y cient√≠fico del clima que no particip√≥ en el nuevo informe: ‚ÄúEstos documentos pueden golpearte como una tonelada de ladrillos, y eso es intencional‚Äù.

author: Lucy West
title: Ryan Chesley scores crucial one-time blast to help lead Team USA to 4-3 shootout WJC win over Czechia
text: Washington Capitals defense prospect Ryan Chesley and the rest of Team USA were victorious today in a shootout thriller against Czechia. The 19-year-old rearguard notched his first point of the tournament in the 4-3 win, scoring an equalizing goal at the end of the second period. Chesley has been integral for the US on the team‚Äôs top defense pairing and was [named one of the squad‚Äôs alternate captains](https://russianmachineneverbreaks.com/2023/12/21/capitals-prospect-ryan-chesley-named-alternate-captain-of-team-usa-for-2024-world-junior-championship/) before the tournament‚Äôs kickoff. The US is undefeated through three Group B preliminary games with one more to come on Sunday. Chesley‚Äôs goal came 14:11 into the second period with the US down 3-2 to Czechia. The marker is his first at the U20 tournament after he recorded just one assist in seven games at last year‚Äôs event. An absolute bomb from Ryan Chelsey üí• [#WorldJuniors] [pic.twitter.com/JEe8YPeIZo] ‚Äî USA Hockey (@usahockey) [December 29, 2023] The strike was assisted by Chesley‚Äôs defense partner and high-scoring Montreal Canadiens prospect Lane Hutson. Hutson started the play by passing the puck through traffic from behind the Czech red line, perfectly setting up Chesley for a big one-time blast that whizzed past goaltender Michael Hrabal. The Minnesota native played 24:58 of total ice time in the win, second most among US players to just Hutson (26:16) and third-most overall in the game. Chesley, the Capitals‚Äô 2022 second-round draft selection, is amid his sophomore season at the University of Minnesota, where he was one of four Gophers to be selected to Team USA‚Äôs preliminary roster. Joining them in Sweden for the tournament is coach Steve Miller, who is an assistant coach for the States. In the NCAA this year, Chesley has two goals and four assists in 18 games. His goal on Friday made him the 49th Minnesota hockey player to score in a World Juniors Tournament, and only the 14th defender to do so. GAME. OVER. üá∫üá∏ [#WorldJuniors]| [@WinmarkResale] [pic.twitter.com/PfF63dUEGQ] ‚Äî USA Hockey (@usahockey) [December 29, 2023] Chesley was not the only Capitals prospect to contribute to the US‚Äô win as Ryan Leonard added an assist on Will Smith‚Äôs goal early in the second period. Leonard combined with his two Boston College linemates Gabe Perreault and Smith to tie the game 2-2 halfway through the contest. The point keeps Leonard producing at a point-per-game rate through three games of the tournament. The 18-year-old winger later got an attempt in the shootout but was denied a real chance at scoring by an unfortunate puck bobble. The feed from Lenny The finish from Smith üëå [#WorldJuniors] [pic.twitter.com/Z9tOyBBvXi] ‚Äî USA Hockey (@usahockey) [December 29, 2023] Isaac Howard eventually put the nail in the coffin for Czechia, seven rounds into the duel. Team USA will take the ice again for the last time in preliminary round action in a New Year‚Äôs Eve battle against an also undefeated Slovakian team to determine the champion of Group B.
